results.title: The Witches (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Lorimar Film Entertainment, Jim Henson Productions, Mark Shivas and Nicolas Roeg
results.brief_description: When nine year old Luke and his grandmother go for a quiet seaside holiday, they stumble upon a witches’ convention, hosted by the Grand High Witch, (Angelica Huston). When Luke becomes a victim of the witches’ scheme to rid Britain of all its children, by transforming them into mice, he devises a plot with his grandmother to finally rid the world of witches. Based on the book by Roald Dahl.

results.title: The Wisdom of crocodiles = Immortality
results.creator_credit: Zenith Productions, David Lascelles, Carolyn Choa and Po Chih Leong
results.brief_description: The Wisdom of crocodiles, directed by Hong Kong veteran director Po Chih Leong, is an elegant thriller set in contemporary London that combines the serial killer and vampire genres. Steven Grlscz is a charming, wealthy man who lures beautiful women and then subjects them to wicked, deathly pursuits. A sprucely variant of the Dracula myth, “The Wisdom of crocodiles” creates its central character, Grlscz, as a complex individual who lives alone in a gothic, decadent, highly ornamental London ‘pad’ and spends his spare time cataloguing the death of his victims. Grlscz’s killer instinct derives from the Dracula myth tradition: he kills in order to sustain his own well-being and life force. Though evidence points to Grlscz as a suspect, his brilliance outsmarts the police; in fact, Inspector Healey, the Catholic police inspector who tails Grlscz, comes to like and respect him after Grlscz saves his life. Soon enough, they develop a friendship and ruminate on philosophic matters of good and evil, black and white, marriage and fidelity, and so on. Steven’s killer instinct is challenged when he meets structural engineer, Anna Levels, whose combination of femininity and worldliness, sensuality and astuteness, vulnerability and independence, ultimately saves her life. Director Po Chih Leong and writer Paul Hoffman have created a sophisticated, engaging thriller that fits complex characters with gorgeous visuals and an inventive soundtrack. Cast includes Jude Law, Elina Lowensohn, Timothy Spall and Kerry Fox.

results.title: The Wings of the dove
results.creator_credit: Miramax Films, Renaissance Dove, Stephen Evans, David Parfitt and Iain Softley
results.brief_description: When Kate (Helena Bonham-Carter) falls in love with middle class journalist Martin (Linus Roache), her benefactor Aunt refuses to accept their union, believing her niece can do better. She offers Kate an ultimatum, stay with her lover and renounce any financial support for herself and her father, or assume her rightful place in society and promise to never see him again. Months later, an American heiress, Millie (Alison Elliot), enters their milieu and Kate forms a friendship with the new visitor. When Kate discovers that Millie is not only rich, but dying, her mind toys with the possibility of finding a way that she and Martin can be together and financially successful- Martin must fall in love with Millie. Set in Venice in the early 1900’s, this lavish period drama is based on the novel by Henry James. Cast includes Elizabeth McGovern, Charlotte Rampling and Michael Gambon.

results.title: The Wind will carry us = Le Vent nous emportera
results.creator_credit: MK2 Productions, Marin Karmitz and Abbas Kiarostami
results.brief_description: Behzad Dourami plays an engineer who arrives with a film crew in an isolated Iranian village high in the mountains. It is not made clear why the men from the city have arrived in the village, except that they seem very interested in the illness and death throes of an old woman. A young boy escorts the men around his home and the engineer becomes familiar with both the landscape and personages of this small rural community. Kiarostami’s films utilise realist conventions - non-actors, real sound and location - to create highly personal and philosophical works that examine the broad existential and theological questions of human life. Whereas the urban men at the beginning of the film are cynical and disparaging of the traditional lifestyle and values of the villagers, what the engineer discovers is that the timeless ethical codes of the village are well suited to dealing with the fundamental issues of life and death. He also discovers that beneath the veneer of stability and order in the village, chaos and change also have their place. Enriched by Mahaoud Kalar’s ravishing cinematography, “The Wind Will Carry Us” is an important addition to Kiarostami’s oeuvre as one of the foremost spiritual and philosophical of contemporary directors. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1999 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: The Wild one [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Stanley Kramer and Laslo Benedek
results.brief_description: A group of youths in a motorcycle gang ride into a small Californian town and begin to terrorize the locals. Johnny, the leader of the gang, falls in love with a woman in town but any hope for their relationship is ruined by both the aggression of his fellow bikers, and the prejudices and closed-mindedness of the town’s people. “The Wild one” is one of many Hollywood movies to represent the emerging sub-cultures of alienated and dissatisfied Western youth who were the immediate predecessors to the generation in the sixties who were to create the upheaval of the “counter- culture”. Initially banned in Australia on its release, “The Wild one” is also notable for Marlon Brando’s electrifying performance as Johnny and its (then) innovative use of a rock and roll music score.

results.title: The Wild bunch [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Phil Feldman and Sam Peckinpah
results.brief_description: In 1913, a gang known as “The Wild Bunch”, rode into a Texas border town disguised as U.S. soldiers. Silently they entered the railroad office and robbed it. Perched on the rooftops above was a ring of hired gunmen waiting for their prey. When the gang emerged they opened fire. An exciting, provocative and influential film that breathed new life into Westerns, it brings together an all-star cast of fine actors at the peak of their talents to play the band of magnificent losers in a dying, lawless West. A documentary, “The Wild Bunch: an album in montage”, as well as a new introduction by Ernest Borgnine precedes the movie.

results.title: The Wicker man
results.creator_credit: British Lion Film Productions, Peter Snell and Robin Hardy
results.brief_description: A spell binding occult thriller by writer Anthony Shaffer. A policeman goes to a remote Scottish Island to investigate the disappearance of a local girl and discovers a society of modern pagans worshipping the ancient gods of Earth, Rain and Sun. They are led by a sinister overlord in erotic rituals and savage ceremonies of human sacrifice and weave a web of hedonistic pleasure and terror around the puritanical, holier-than-thou policeman. When he finally discovers what happened to the girl, his nightmare is only just beginning!

results.title: The White balloon
results.creator_credit: CMI, Dendy Films, Ferdos Films and Jafar Panahi
results.brief_description: This wonderful motion picture is the story of a young Iranian girl’s search for the perfect goldfish to release in her pond to encourage good luck in the New Year. However, when she loses the money her mother has given her, young Razieh and her brother seek their fortunes in modern day Tehran. This visually ravishing contemporary retelling of “The Red Balloon”, reveals much about the culture of the Muslim world. By filming through a child’s eyes, director Jafar Panahi reveals a world of incidental cruelty, a world which often rushes by too fast to listen to the desires of children. There is a darkness in “The White Balloon”, not explicit, but a sadness about the opportunities adults lose in understanding the world of their child. As in all the best fairy-tales, this is a profoundly humane story. The screenplay is by acclaimed director Abbas Kiarostami. Winner of the Camera D’Or at the 1995 Cannes Film Festival.
